II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

A. 

Performance Indicators and Analysis  

Following  cessation  of  economic  transfers  from  the  former  Soviet  Union  after 
2. 
independence in 1991, ethnic pressures contributed to a civil war that began in 1992 and lasted 
until 1997. Macroeconomic conditions worsened until 1997 when the economy started showing 
signs of recovery. Real gross domestic product (GDP) in 2002 was 60% of that in 1991. GDP 
per capita in 2001 was $162. Inflation, although lower than in the early 1990s, is still high, while 
real  wages  have  decreased  significantly  since  1991.  The  aftermath  of  civil  war,  together  with 
economic depression, has put more than 80% of the population below the national poverty line.  
 
The  Government’s  Poverty  Reduction  Strategy  Paper  (PRSP),1  endorsed  by  the 
3. 
parliament  in  June  2002,  sets  out  efficient  and  fair  provision  of  basic  social  services  to 
vulnerable  groups  as  an  approach  to  reducing  poverty.  The  Government's  medium-term 
strategy  has  been  set  in  line  with  the  poverty  reduction  strategy  under  its  poverty  partnership 
agreement  with  the  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  in  December  2002.  The  medium-term 
strategy  stipulates  that,  for  social  sectors,  ADB  and  the  Government  will  focus  on  improving 
social  service  delivery  to  vulnerable  groups  and  rationalizing  social  sector  expenditures  to 
ensure equitable access to quality education and health services. The Millennium Development 
Goals (MDGs) for 2015 form the key basis for the Government to monitor performance targets. 
The project framework in Appendix 1 provides key project targets. 
 
4. 
The  education  system  is  the  responsibility  of  the  Ministry  of  Education  (MOE)  and  is 
administered through a network of education departments in each of three regions (oblasts), as 
well  as  in  Dushanbe,  in  the  Regions  of  Republican  Subordination  (RSS),  and  in  the  districts 
(raion). Compulsory basic education is 9 years, reduced from 11 years in 1996 due to resource 
constraints.  It  is  free,  as  per  the  constitution,  and  consists  of  4  years  of  primary  (grades  1–4) 
and 5 years of lower secondary (grades 5–9). Upper secondary comprises grades 10 and 11. 
Technical and vocational education and training is available after grade 9 (3 or 4 years) or after 
grade 11 (2 years). Public and private institutions provide tertiary education, with increasing cost 
recovery at both types of institutions.     
 
5. 
Tajikistan has a rapidly growing population, with children under 17 years old comprising 
almost  50%  of  the  total  population  of  6.3  million  in  2000.  The  fertility  rate—which  was  5.0  in 
1990 and declined to 3.7 in 2000—remains the highest in Central Asia, and the population risks 
doubling  every  20  years.  Primary  and  general  secondary  education  will  have  an  additional 
850,000  students  by  2015,  and  social  services  must  be  ready  to  accommodate  a  rapidly 
growing population.

B. 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

7. 
Tajikistan inherited a highly centralized education system with a well-developed network 
of educational institutions, well-trained and -qualified teachers, almost universal access to and 
gender  balance  in  compulsory  basic  education,  and  almost  universal  literacy  (Appendix  2). 
Educational indicators were comparable with middle-income countries. These achievements are 
now threatened. 
 
8. 
Declining Opportunities for Education. Following independence, declining resources 
and rising poverty have harmed the education system. Budget allocations to sustain the sector 
have  been  constrained,  as  has  the  demand  for  education,  as  represented  by  the  opportunity 
costs  of  participation  and  poor  employment  opportunities.  Enrollment  in  preschool  and  TVET 
has collapsed, but increased 19% from 1991 to 2001 in primary and general secondary to more 
than 1.5 million. This comes in spite of a decline in the gross enrollment ratio2 in basic education 
from 94.9% in 1990 to less than 84.3% in 2000. Gender imbalance is emerging particularly at 
the  upper  secondary  level,  with  the  proportion  of  girls  declining  from  49%  in  1991  to  38%  in 
2001.  While  enrollment  has  declined  in  primary  education,  actual  attendance  may  be  even 
lower.  Many  qualified  teachers  have  left  the  profession  because  of  very  low  salaries.  Many 
students do not have textbooks or learning materials, and school buildings were badly damaged 
from the civil war and poor maintenance. More than 40% of parents have told surveys they are 
dissatisfied with education quality.3 The current generation in Tajikistan is at risk of receiving a 
poorer education than the previous one. 
 
9. 
Need  for  a  Coherent  Vision  and  Strategy  for  Equitable,  Sustainable  Education. 
Since independence in 1991, a significantly reduced budget has been inadequate to sustain a 
highly developed education system. The PRSP proposes new measures to address challenges 
facing  the  sector.  Tajikistan  envisaged  some  decentralization  in  its  new  Law  on  Education 
(1994), but this strategy was largely employed to shift financial responsibility downward to local 
governments  and  parents  who  lack  commensurate  capacity,  conceptual  clarity,  or  resources. 
The  Government  wants  to  introduce  a  new  financing  system,  involve  local  governments  and 
nongovernment  organizations  (NGOs),  improve  quality  through  various  measures,  and  make 
appropriate  legal  changes  and  amendments.  The  Government  needs  to  develop  a  coherent, 
realistic vision and strategy given that the financial needs of the sector are not affordable within 
the current economic context. 
 
10.  Weak  Information  Base  and  Poor  Capacity  to  Prioritize  Systemic  Reform  and 
Address  Inherent  Inequities.  MOE  recognizes  gaps  in  the  information  systems  that  support 
education  planning,  such  as  the  lack  of  information  on  learner  performance.  For  planning 
purposes, MOE has access only to broad averages on attendance and distribution of education 
inputs.  While  it  is  possible  to  analyse  resource  distribution  across  districts,  it  is  not  easy  to

Information  on  the  quality  of  school  management  is  not  used  to  design  training  programs  for 
school  principals  and  parents’  committees;  indeed,  few  such  programs  are  available.  Data 
exists within MOE but is not integrated for coherent strategies or plans.  
 
Because an integrated education management information system (EMIS) and adequate 
11. 
district-based  information  systems  are  lacking,  it  is  difficult  to  ascertain  whether  education  is 
equitably  provided  across  or  within  districts.  Although  there  is  substantial  circumstantial 
evidence of inequities, these are difficult to quantify. If little is known about inequities in terms of 
educational inputs, less is known about variations in learning outcomes. It is therefore difficult, if 
not impossible, to plan for increased equity or quality.  
 
12. 
Inequitable  Opportunities  for  Teaching  and  Learning.  The 
education  system  that  was  conceived  and  developed  for  a  socialist  society  is  now  under 
pressure  to  adapt  to  a  market-based,  internationally  competitive  society.  The  teaching 
profession is unattractive because of low salaries, poor working conditions, and a lack of career 
opportunities.  The  overall  teacher-to-student  ratio  of  1:15,4  average  workload  of  14–18  hours 
per  week,  and  single-subject  specialization  of  teachers  in  grades  5–11  make  the  system 
inefficient  and  expensive,  and  it  absorbs  resources  that  could  be  used  to  improve  teacher 
salaries or provide more textbooks. 
 
13.  MOE made efforts after independence, most recently in 2002, to add new subjects to the 
curriculum and, in particular, to build national identity. However, the already heavy course load 
has increased further with the introduction of new subjects. In some cases, the new curriculum 
requires specialization to start from grade 5 instead of grade 9, as in the past. The curriculum 
must be made more relevant to the issues dominating Tajikistan's current social, political, and 
educational  development,  such  as  the  movement  toward  a  market  economy;  a  transparent, 
democratic, and just society; attempts to improve system efficiency; and a focus on the quality 
of  learning  outcomes  in  schools.  There  is  an  urgent  need  to  bring  efficiency  into  both  the 
curriculum  development  system  and  the  actual  curriculum  through  further  reform  focused  on 
learning  outcomes.  Curriculum  development  is  currently  coordinated  by  the  Department  of 
Science, which has relied on ad-hoc groups and is fragmented as a result.

15.

Lessons  Learned.  Experience  from  the  ongoing  social  sector  rehabilitation  project

III. 

THE PROPOSED PROJECT 

A. 

Objective 

21. 
The  goal  of  the  ESRP  is  to  contribute  to  the  Government’s  overall  strategic  goal  of 
poverty  reduction  by  improving  equitable  access  to,  and  completion  of,  quality  primary  and 
general  secondary  education.  This  goal  focuses  on  girls and  vulnerable  groups, particularly  in 
rural areas. The ESRP’s objective is to support MOE’s education reform program by helping it to 
develop  a  prioritized,  costed  National  Education  Development  Framework  (NEDF)  to  improve 
efficiency, equity, and quality in primary and general secondary education.  
 
B. 

Components and Outputs 

22. 
The ESRP has three components: (i) system efficiency and management, (ii) equitable 
access  and  completion,  and  (iii)  quality  improvement.  The  ESRP  will  have  national  and  pilot 
district  components.  Pilot  components  will  be  implemented  in  five  rural  districts:  Roshkala,  in 
Gorno Badakshan Autonomous Region (GBAR); Kulyab, in Khatlon Region; Ayni and Gornaya 
Matcha,  in  Sughd  Region;  and  Garm,  in  RRS.  The  pilot  districts  were  selected  based  on  the 
level and severity of poverty, the level of infant and maternal mortality, girls’ enrollment rate, and 
proportion  of  female  teachers  (Appendix  4).  Geographical  variation  was  also  considered.  The 
ESRP’s goal will have a direct positive impact on Tajikistan’s PRSP, and will target primary and 
general secondary education, with particular focus on girls and vulnerable groups, contributing 
to  achievement  of  key  MDGs.  Parallel  implementation  of  the  ESRP  with  another  in  the  health 
sector  in  the  same  districts  will  particularly  benefit  community  mobilization,  child  health,  and 
early education.

involving school communities in organizing training, and equipping and rehabilitating education

population in five of the poorest districts; and (v) enhancing the capacity of education personnel  
to  work  for  girls  and  vulnerable  groups  at  all  levels.  The  focus  on  gender  equity  and  school

64.

D. 

Social Analysis 

68. 
The  ESRP  aims  to  increase  equity  and  effectiveness  in  the  provision  of  educational 
benefits by focusing on five pilot districts disadvantaged by natural disasters, civil strife, poverty, 
and vulnerable minority populations. Women and girls are also a specific focus. The ESRP will 
set up social measures likely to benefit the vulnerable groups, women, and children based on 
comprehensive school mapping in each pilot district. The summary poverty reduction and social 
strategy form is in Appendix 17. 
 

1. 

Poverty Impact 

69. 
Poverty  remains  Tajikistan’s  central  development  issue.  Tajikistan  was  one  of  the 
poorest republics even before the dissolution of the former Soviet Union, despite large annual 
budget transfers from Moscow. The economic collapse of the early 1990s and subsequent civil 
strife  caused  poverty  to  intensify  and  spread.  About  83%  of  the  population  was  below  the 

 

  

17

poverty line in 1999.7 Poverty rates were high for households with many children, widows with 
small  children,  the  unemployed,  people  without  access  to  any  kind  of  social  safety  net  (the 
disabled,  school  dropouts,  street  children,  and  the  elderly),  single  pensioners,  returnees,  and 
internally displaced people. Rural areas have higher and deeper incidences of poverty, and the 
direct incidences of poverty occur in remote mountainous areas where the population is mostly 
very young or elderly. The five pilot districts are considered among the poorest in Tajikistan, and 
the lower half of the population is intended to benefit more from the ESRP than the upper half. 
 
Poverty  manifests  itself  in  different  forms,  and  disproportionately  affects  vulnerable 
70. 
groups  in  the  education  sector.  Meager  budgetary  allocations  to  education,  as  well  as  formal 
and  informal  charges  at  different  levels,  mean  that  the  lowest  economic  quintile  has  to 
contribute 17.0% of household income to education, compared to just 5.3% for the top quintile. 
Preschool  enrollment,  particularly  of  children  from  poor  households,  has  declined  sharply 
because they are unable to pay, so their children are less well prepared to perform in school. 
The poor have greater difficulty getting textbooks and learning materials because of associated 
charges.  Health  problems,  greater  opportunity  costs,  and  inadequate  clothing  for  bad  weather 
mean that regular school attendance among the poor has declined, more so in rural areas and 
in upper grades. A gender gap is emerging, particularly at upper and post-secondary levels, with 
a consistent trend across all regions. These analyses will guide poverty indexing and targeting 
under the ESRP. 
 

2. 

Women 

71. 
Prior to independence, Tajikistan achieved high adult literacy (99% in 1990) and gender 
parity  in  educational  participation.  However,  in  recent  years,  girls’  enrolment  and  attendance, 
particularly at the upper secondary level, is lower than boys’. The proportion of female teachers 
has been rising steadily since 1991, and females comprised about 45.7% of the teaching force 
in primary and general secondary education in 2001 (against 37% in 1991). But the decline in 
girls’  enrollment  in  grades  10  and  11,  particularly  in  remote  locations,  may  limit  the  pool  of 
female  teachers.  Women  in  their  20s  are  slightly  less  educated  than  those  in  their  30s, 
indicating  that  greater  efforts  are  required  to  enroll  more  females,  particularly  at  the  upper-
secondary  level.  Women,  when  they  work,  are  concentrated  in  the  lowest-paid  sectors— 
agriculture, education, and health—where wages are insufficient. 
 
72. 
The proportion of girls enrolled in grades 10 and 11 in the five project districts is about 
36%, or less than the national average of 38%. The proportion of female teachers is about 35%, 
less  than  the  national  proportion  of  46%.  The  ESRP  will  make  targeted  efforts  to  ensure 
increased enrollment of girls and a greater proportion of female teachers in project schools. 
 

3.

73. 
The constitution indicates that no person shall be discriminated against on the basis of 
ethnic origin. The constitution also guarantees minorities equal access to education. According 
to some NGOs working in the pilot districts, ethnic minorities are well integrated and enjoy the 
same  health  and  education  status,  except  for  the  elderly  Russian  population  that  receives 
support  from  NGOs.  The  ESRP  falls  under  category  “C”  in  terms  of  minority  groups.  More 
detailed information on ethnic minorities is provided in Appendix 4.

7. 
In  line  with  the  Government’s  policy  stipulations,  the  ADB-supported  education  sector 
review proposes key reforms, including (i) constructing a national education system, (ii) moving 
away  from  the  command-and-control  mode  of  educational  delivery  that  characterized  the 
previous  centralized  system,  (iii)  modernizing  system  governance  and  management,  and  (iv) 
developing  a  curriculum  to  better  prepare  its  citizens  for  this  century.  A  key  challenge  is  that 
Tajikistan can ill afford to run the system it inherited at independence. Despite funding agency 
driven reform efforts over the last 5 years, Tajikistan still faces similar problems: infrastructural 
ruin  and  neglect,  displaced  communities,  institutional  breakdown,  a  brain  drain  of  highly 
qualified  experts,  the  emergence  of  a  shadow  economy  that  rivals  the  “official”  economy,  and 
the  deterioration  of  public  services.  More  recently,  external  funding  agencies  in  the  education 
sector have begun to improve coordination to support the Government.

adequately addressed in small-scale pilot projects are yet to be taken to scale, while the rest of

pressed  forward  with  the  formal  adoption  of  a  poverty  reduction  strategy  that  recognizes  the 
educational development as central to relieving poverty. Tajikistan has publicly committed itself 
to education and educational spending as a percentage of GDP.

afford  the  education  system  of  its  past.  Since  the  system  is  making  efforts  to  align  with 
democracy  and  an  emerging  market  economy,  serious  care  is  needed  to  adopt  an  efficient, 
sustainable approach to financing. While there is a need to increase resources for education, it 
is  equally  important  to  streamline  structural  problems.  A  major  project  objective  is  to  help  the 
Government  to  move  in  this  direction  by  laying  the  foundation  for  a  longer-term  financing 
framework.  The  design  comprises  components  that  support  management  and  technical 
efficiency to make investment more affordable and sustainable. 
 
12. 
From  2000  to  2002,  the  social  sector  absorbed  over  a  third  of  the  total  government 
expenditure.  The  share  of  social spending  in  total  state  expenditures grew  from  about  34%  in 
2000  (4.7%  of  GDP)  to  42%  (5.9%  of  GDP)  in  2002,  indicating  the  Government’s  rising 
commitment to improving social services. After significant declines in the mid-1990s, education 
spending  as  a  share  of  total  state  expenditures  has  increased  steadily  from  15.3%  in  2000  to 
17.6%  in  2002.  Per  capita  spending  grew  from  $2.86  to  $4.34  during  the  same  period.  It  is 
projected that government and per capita spending will reach 18.9% and $4.95 respectively in 
2003.  By international comparison, however, Tajikistan’s annual education spending as a share 
of GDP has been the lowest in Central Asia at around 2.5% in 2001. 
 
13. 
Private  expenditure  in  education  is  about  50%  of  the  total  expenditure,  with  almost  all 
families  spending  some  money  on  education,  the  bulk  of  it  at  the  tertiary  level.3  Following  the 
Law  on  Education  (1994),  several  private  schools  and  universities  have  been  established  but 
private  enrolment  is  only  about  1%.  Given  the  tight  fiscal  scenario  and  inability  of  the 
Government  to  increase  allocations  significantly,  private  funding  is  needed.  Efforts  are 
necessary  to  target  public  resources  to  children  from  poor  families  at  all  levels  and  to  make 
financing more transparent to improve quality and equity in education.
